DataElement.preferredName: Gross Residual Malignant Neoplasm Surgical Procedure Performed Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator whether there was surgical removal or excision of a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues, visible to the naked eye and remaining following treatment.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Gross Residual Malignant Neoplasm Surgical Procedure Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues, visible to the naked eye and remaining following treatment being surgically removed or excised.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Gross Residual Malignant Neoplasm Surgical Procedure
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Visible to the naked eye.:Remaining or left behind.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:Used for operative procedures on organs, regions, or tissues in the treatment of diseases, including tissue section by lasers. It excludes transplantation, for which "transplantation" is used.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have residual tumor after surgery (any single site) exceeding 2 cm in maximum dimension?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Is the patient optimally resected (gross residual disease less than 1 cm)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text3
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have gross residual or metastatic tumor findings following complete surgical treatment for uterine LMS?

ReferenceDocuments.name: COG CRF Text 1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Was gross tumor found by surgeon?

ReferenceDocuments.name: COG CRF Text 2
ReferenceDocuments.description: If gross tumor found, was a surgical resection attempted?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text 4
ReferenceDocuments.description: Was there gross residual disease left unremoved

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text5
ReferenceDocuments.description: Surgical resection of all gross disease

ReferenceDocuments.name: COG CRF Text 4
ReferenceDocuments.description: Was the lesion surgically removed since the last imaging assessment?
